text: Then called I upon the name of the LORD; O LORD, I beseech thee, deliver my soul.
text_kjv: Then called I upon the name of the LORD; O LORD, I beseech thee, deliver my soul.
text_niv: Then I called on the name of the Lord:“O Lord, save me!”
text_esv: Then I called on the name of the LORD: “O LORD, I pray, deliver my soul!”
text_nlt: Then I called on the name of the LORD:“Please, LORD, save me!”
text_msg: then I called out to God for help:"Please, God!" I cried out."Save my life!"
text_nasb: Then I called upon the name of the LORD: 'O LORD, I beseech You, save my life!'
context: Psalm 116 is a psalm of thanksgiving, likely written after a period of intense suffering and near-death experience. Understanding its context requires appreciating the precariousness of life in ancient Israel. Disease, famine, and warfare were constant threats. The author, experiencing such hardship, would have felt utterly helpless. The act of calling upon the Lord, mentioned in verse 4, was a common practice in times of distress. Prayer was not a passive activity but an active reaching out to a personal God believed to intervene in human affairs. Ancient Israelites viewed the soul (nephesh) as the seat of life, intimately connected to physical well-being. To be delivered from peril meant the preservation of both physical life and spiritual integrity. The language of 'beseeching' underscores the desperate nature of the psalmist's plea. The repetition of 'O LORD' emphasizes the personal relationship and the psalmist's earnest supplication. This psalm reflects a society deeply dependent on divine intervention, where health and safety were perceived as blessings bestowed by God. The psalm is also personal testimony – the psalmist is recounting an experience and offering praise because God has answered his prayer. Therefore, the psalm’s historical context is not just about the historical setting, but also the personal background of the author and their reliance on God amidst great difficulty.
meaning: Psalm 116:4 encapsulates the essence of a believer's relationship with God: a recognition of dependence and a confident appeal to His mercy. The act of 'calling upon the name of the LORD' signifies more than simply uttering words; it represents a complete surrender of control and a reliance on God's power. In the Old Testament, the name of God is not merely a label but a revelation of His character and attributes. To call upon His name is to invoke His presence and His power. The phrase 'I beseech thee' conveys a sense of urgency and humility. It acknowledges that deliverance is not a right but a gift, freely given by God's grace. The plea to 'deliver my soul' highlights the understanding that true deliverance extends beyond physical rescue. It encompasses the preservation of spiritual life and the restoration of inner peace. This verse reflects the theological concept of God as a refuge and a deliverer. It affirms the belief that God hears the cries of His people and responds to their needs. It also underscores the importance of prayer as a means of connecting with God and experiencing His saving power. The theological underpinning rests on the character of God as one who is both all-powerful (capable of delivering) and merciful (willing to deliver). It is a testament to the promise found throughout scripture that God is near to the brokenhearted and saves those who are crushed in spirit. It expresses the truth that God desires and is available to hear and answer sincere cries for help.
application: Psalm 116:4 offers profound practical application for modern believers navigating the complexities of life. In moments of overwhelming stress, anxiety, or despair, this verse serves as a powerful reminder to actively call upon the name of the Lord. This means intentionally setting aside time for prayer, speaking directly to God about your fears, concerns, and needs. It involves recognizing your limitations and acknowledging God's sovereignty. 'Beseeching' God implies approaching Him with humility and a sincere desire for His intervention, understanding that deliverance is ultimately a gift of grace, not something earned. Don't just passively hope for things to get better; actively engage in prayer. The phrase 'deliver my soul' is especially relevant in a world that often prioritizes material success and fleeting pleasures. It reminds us to seek deliverance not only from physical hardships but also from spiritual dangers such as temptation, doubt, and despair. Cultivate a habit of regularly praying for the well-being of your soul, seeking God's guidance and protection. When facing trials, it's easy to isolate ourselves and rely on our own strength, but this verse encourages us to turn to God first, trusting in His power to deliver us. Remember that prayer isn't just a last resort, but a vital lifeline that connects us to the source of all hope and strength. Use this verse as a catalyst for honest conversation with God, sharing your vulnerabilities and seeking His peace and direction. Keep a prayer journal to track your prayers and God's answers, reinforcing your faith in His faithfulness. Finally, when God answers your prayers, remember to offer thanksgiving, just as the psalmist did, solidifying your reliance on Him for future needs.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you today, acknowledging my need for your deliverance. Like the psalmist, I find myself facing challenges that seem overwhelming. I call upon your name, O Lord, knowing that you are the source of all strength and hope. I beseech you, in your infinite mercy, to deliver my soul from the anxieties and fears that plague me. Grant me peace that surpasses all understanding. Guide my steps and lead me in the path of righteousness. Help me to trust in your promises and to rely on your unwavering love. Thank you for hearing my prayer and for being a God who is always near to those who call upon your name. I offer you my gratitude and praise. Amen.

faqs.answer: Calling on the Lord's name signifies more than uttering the name 'Lord'. It involves invoking His character, authority, and presence. It's an act of faith, trusting in His power to answer prayer and acknowledging His sovereignty in your life. It expresses total reliance on God's ability to help.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: What does it mean to 'call upon the name of the Lord'?

faqs.answer: In the Old Testament, the soul (nephesh) isn't solely a spiritual entity, but is intertwined with physical life. 'Deliver my soul' suggests a plea for overall well-being, including physical health, emotional stability, and spiritual protection from harm or destruction.
faqs.question: Q2: How is 'soul' (nephesh) understood in this context?

faqs.answer: 'Beseech' conveys humility and earnestness in prayer. It acknowledges God's sovereignty and our dependence on His grace. It is not a demand but an expression of profound need and a respectful request for divine intervention.
faqs.question: Q3: What is the significance of 'beseech' in this verse?

faqs.answer: While God hears and answers prayers, this verse doesn't guarantee exemption from all hardship. Instead, it assures us of God's presence and support during trials. Deliverance can mean rescue, strength to endure, or ultimate salvation and eternal life.
faqs.question: Q4: Is this verse a promise that God will always deliver us from hardship?

faqs.answer: Even when prayer feels difficult, intentionally choose to call on the Lord. Begin with simple words, acknowledging your lack of desire and asking for His help to pray. The act of reaching out, even weakly, can open the door for God's grace to flow.
faqs.question: Q5: How can I apply this verse when I don't feel like praying?
